Nor is this the only form of transition repeatedly adopted by Ovid. Another method is to introduce stories as told by spectatore, sometimes to convince the ineredulous, sometimes, like the story ol Assorus already mentioned, because some similarity in the catastrophe prompte their recollection. Pirithous doubts the metamorphosis ol Perimele narreted by Achelous,¹ but is silenced by Lelex, who relatos the story oi Baucis and Philemon, whereupon Achelous himself gives further proof of the divine power. The fate ol Niobe recalls another instance of Latona's vengeance,² the transformation to frogs ol the Lysian peasants who insulted her, and again the fate of Marsyas, flayed alive by her son Apollo and meta morphosed to a river. Or a story is told within a story by way of warning or encouragement.⁸ The crow endeavours to deter the raven from revealing to Apollo the iaithlessness oi Coronis, by relating the disgrace inflieted by Pallas upon herself for a like indiscretion. Sometimes a journey gives occasion ior adventures or allows the introduction of local
